author: bitmexresearch
content:
Really sorry, I am sure this has come up before. Please can I ask about the merge

Currently I run Geth and Prysm. Post merge, will I only need to run Geth to validate the chain and validate transactions, or do I still need Prysm?

author: bitmexresearch
content: ame with the ETH testnet

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: hivetests2.ethdevops.io

author: bitmexresearch
content: So only geth is fine?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: No you need both an EL and a CL client

author: bitmexresearch
content: on the Ropstein chain, if we have Geth, what settings do we need to get on teh right chain?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: geth --ropsten

author: bitmexresearch
content: So the chains merge, but you still need two clients? Is that forever or will you evntually need only one?

author: bitmexresearch
content: I think we are stuck on the wrong chain, the non-merge chain, and we may to roll-back

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: No that will stay forever

author: bitmexresearch
content: To clarify, we are on the wrong Ropsten chain

author: bitmexresearch
content: ok thanks

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: If you run a CL node, geth should automatically move to the correct chain

author: bitmexresearch
content: Why would you need two clients post merge when there is one chain?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Because the one chain actually contains the other chain

author: sky.cactus
content: They handle different pieces of the system.  The consensus client (Prysm in your case) handles consensus (deciding which block is canonical), while the execution client (geth in your case) handles EVM execution, state, and a bunch of other things.

author: bitmexresearch
content: Ok, that explains it, thanks, in the future why cant geth also decide which block is canonical, so that we only need one client?

author: bitmexresearch
content: So in our Ropstein case, we need to install Prysm, connect Geth to it, and then it should go on the right chain

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: We could do that with a light client on the CL (and we have a prototype for it already) but we are not ready to ship that yet

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: Yes exactly

author: bitmexresearch
content: perfect thanks

author: g11tech
content: but "finalized" and "safe" tags should give the correct chain already, no?

author: g11tech
content: (if implemented)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: No, because we can't choose between the chains fed by our peers, we can't sync to post-merge chains

author: g11tech
content: ohh with no CL connected at all

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: We could optimistically sync from our peers, but then we would have no guarantees whatsoever

author: philngo
content:
Lodestar has also just released a quick setup guide for anyone that wants to easily setup and run Sepolia (or other testnets) via our merge-script via Docker. It supports Lodestar + Nethermind/Besu/Geth so you can try out the different EL combinations for greater diversity going into the merges. This will also be incorporated for Goerli/Prater and Mainnet to help people easily spin up these combinations with Lodestar.
Quick Setup guide: https://hackmd.io/@philknows/rJegZyH9q
Repo: https://github.com/ChainSafe/lodestar/tree/unstable/merge-scripts
